Award.AwardTitle: Electrical Engineering Research and Technology Transfer Experience for Undergraduates

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This renewal REU Site program will continue to provide individually challenging experiences in research and well-organized integrative team activities and professional development in ethics, entrepreneurship, and systems engineering to accomplish its objective of attracting talented undergraduate students and providing a program of unique, high quality, and balanced research activities that positively impact the participants' lifelong career choices in engineering research.

The REU site renewal will continue to broaden opportunities and provide enhanced research experiences for talented and diversified domestic undergraduate students, especially from the underrepresented groups. Furthermore, the involvement of the undergraduates in engineering research with exposure to ethical issues in tech transfer has implications well beyond the technical scope of the individual research projects, and the inclusion of entrepreneurship shows how research products from the lab transition to products that impact society. It is expected that undergraduate participants will gain successful admission to graduate school, and become outstanding researchers in their chosen fields and strong contributors to society both as individual researchers and as team oriented professionals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the 2011 - 2013 NSF REU Program at Penn State were to provide individually challenging experiences in research and well-organized integrative team activities in ethics, entrepreneurship, and professional development to accomplish its objective of attracting talented undergraduate students and providing a program of unique, high quality, and balanced research activities that positively impact the lifelong career choices of the participants in engineering research. During the program, the students explored a wide range of research and investigated how this research is transitioned to commercial ventures.

Program activities for the 2011-2013 EEREU Summer Programs at Penn State are summarized in the Annual Research Journal files that were attached to the annual 2011, 2012, and 2013 reports  reports, and which can also be downloaded from the Penn State REU website. Each student became engaged in a research project, under the guidance of his or her faculty mentor, in laboratories located in the Department of Electrical Engineering and the Materials Research Institute. The students were also guided in understanding how the research they were doing, whether fundamental or applied, could have an impact on everyday life and how it transitions from the lab to product development. As part of their research project, the students are challenged to find opportunities for commercializing their research. Understanding the innovation pipeline will ensure that this next generation of researchers will keep the U.S. competitive globally.

The EEREU program also provided an array of group activities including a Weekly Scientific Seminar Series that introduced a broad range of research topics to the students. There were also field trips that allowed the students to visit prominent local and regional industries, entrepreneurial ventures (including some initiated by Penn State EE alumni), and research sites. The students also participated in weekly workshops on ethics and entrepreneurship that engage the students in debate and analyses of ethical issues and entrepreneurial practices in Electrical Engineering. One of the major activities of the 11-year Penn State EEREU program was the Annual EEREU Symposium held at University Park, where the EEREU students summarize their research experiences and present their findings at a full day symposium. The students prepared papers that were reviewed by their mentors. Alumni of the REU program indicated high interest in attending graduate school.

In 2011, with NSF and supplemental support ten students were funded from this EEREU site grant, one student was funded by an individual NSF research grant at Penn State that has REU supplement funding, one student was funded by matching funds from the College of engineering, and another was funded through the Summer Research Opportunities Program at Penn State, resulting in a total of thirteen students participating in the 2011 EEREU summer program. Four of the participants were female engineering students and one was a Hispanic minority from the University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez. Demographically, the thirteen students represented twelve different institutions, including American River College, James Madison University, University of Florida, New Mexico State University, Cooper Union College, Washington State University, Washington University St. Louis, George Mason University, West Virginia Wesleyan College, University of Rochester,  University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez, Penn State University at Harrisburg and Penn State University at University Park.

In 2012, with NSF and supplemental support a total of twelve students participated in the EEREU summer program.
